source_id: STP824-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_6th Volume_045_chunk7
evidence_span: the model of delayed hydrogen cracking can be used only where the stress gradient can be defined by linear elastic fracture mechanics (LEFM); that is, it can be used for cracks down to a size where LEFM no longer applies

source_id: STP824-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_6th Volume_045_chunk7
evidence_span: If the surface were absolutely smooth, a tensile load would give a negligible stress gradient and hydride formation and crack growth under isothermal conditions would not occur

source_id: STP824-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_6th Volume_045_chunk7
evidence_span: Engineeringly smooth surfaces do contain small surface defects and thus stress gradients
